byline.contributor: Cecilia Kang reported from Washington, and Emily Steel from New York.
byline.original: By CECILIA KANG and EMILY STEEL

abstract: Federal Communications Commission announces proposal to allow subscribers to cable and satellite television services to pick devices they use to watch programming; technology companies cheer proposal while cable television industry criticizes it, as current system compels almost all cable customers to use device leased by cable companies for average of $231 per year.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission wants to make it easier for subscribers to choose TV devices, and for manufacturers to introduce them.

headline.main: F.C.C. Proposes Changes in Cable Set-Top Box Market
headline.print_headline: Cable Box Stranglehold Is a Target of the F.C.C.

snippet: The Federal Communications Commission wants to make it easier for subscribers to choose TV devices, and for manufacturers to introduce them.
